Disclaimer: 
The content of our website has been compiled with meticulous care and to the best of our knowledge. However, we cannot assume any liability for the up-to-dateness, completeness, or accuracy of any of the pages. Pursuant to § 7 para. 1 TMG (German Telemedia Act), we are responsible for our own content on these pages in accordance with general laws. However, pursuant to §§ 8 to 10 TMG, we are not obligated to monitor transmitted or stored external information. Once we have become aware of a specific infringement of the law, we will immediately remove the content in question. Any liability concerning this matter can only be assumed from the point in time at which the infringement becomes known to us.
External Links: 
Our website contains links to third-party websites (“external links”). As the content of these websites is not under our control, we cannot assume any liability for such external content. In all cases, the provider of information of the linked websites is liable for the content and accuracy of the information provided. At the point in time when the links were placed, no infringements of the law were recognizable to us. As soon as an infringement of the law becomes known to us, we will immediately remove the link in question.
Copyright: 
The content and works published on this website are governed by the copyright laws of [Country]. Any duplication, processing, distribution, or any form of commercialization of such material beyond the scope of the copyright law shall require the prior written consent of its respective author or creator.
Privacy Policy: 

geo:truth Nonprofit Research Project
Effective Date: August 1, 2019
1. Introduction geo:truth (“we”, “our”, “us”) is committed to protecting and respecting your privacy. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, disclose, and safeguard your information when you visit our website [www.geotruth.org], as well as your rights in relation to your personal data.
2. Information We Collect We may collect and process the following types of information about you:

Personal Identification Information: Name, email address, phone number, mailing address, etc.
Technical Data: IP address, browser type, operating system, referral source, length of visit, page views, and website navigation paths.
Usage Data: Information about how you use our website, products, and services.
Communications: Content of messages you send us, including emails and other forms of communication.

3. How We Use Your Information We use the information we collect in the following ways:

To provide, operate, and maintain our website.
To improve, personalize, and expand our website.
To understand and analyze how you use our website.
To develop new products, services, features,

If you have any concerns about privacy, please email us: admin@geo:truth.org

title: Our Team
text:
I am a geospatial epidemiologist. I am passionate about health equity and geospatial epidemiology. I love food and I love coding. But since I can't eat code, I automate my hydroponic garden to grow my food- Oh, of course, using code. 







 


I am a fun person. I am passionate about things that matter. I love horse riding, hiking. I am a python programmer, I am really a plumber, code plumber and can patch together some mean, beef automations that solve problems and probably leak more problems down the line.




 


I am a rockstar. I am passionate about health equity and geospatial. I love to rock and roll. I support the team's projects to make sure no one is snoozing on the job, except if they are new parents (only exception). I also make a mean boss both at home and at work. Now get to work!













  
    You can support our work with a coffee if you'd like to:

title: Every Geospatial Professional Needs a Portfolio
text:
Why Every Geospatial Professional + Researcher Needs a Professional Portfolio
Hello, budding geospatial professionals and curious readers! Whether you’re fresh out of university or deep into your career, having a professional portfolio is not just a nice-to-have; it’s a game-changer. If you’re wondering why, buckle up! We’re about to explore why creating and maintaining a professional portfolio is essential for your success in the geospatial field.


Showcasing Your Skills and Personality
Imagine this: you’re at a networking event, and someone asks what you do. Instead of just telling them, what if you could show them? A professional portfolio lets you do just that. It’s a visual and interactive way to present your work, from GIS maps to spatial analysis projects. Potential employers, clients, or collaborators can see firsthand what you’re capable of and a touch of your personality. Seeing is believing, after all!


Standing Out in a Crowded Field
The geospatial industry is growing rapidly. With more professionals entering the field, it’s crucial to stand out. A portfolio sets you apart from the crowd. It’s your personal brand, reflecting your style, expertise, and passion. When you apply for a job or a research grant, a well-organized portfolio can be the deciding factor that puts you ahead of the competition.


Keeping Track of Your Achievements
Let’s face it, it’s easy to forget the details of all the projects you’ve worked on. Your portfolio acts as a living document of your career. It helps you keep track of your achievements, big and small. This is especially handy when updating your resume or preparing for performance reviews. Plus, looking back at your accomplishments can be a great confidence booster!


Demonstrating Your Growth
A portfolio isn’t just about showcasing your best work; it’s also about showing your journey. It highlights your growth and development over time. Employers and collaborators appreciate seeing how you’ve progressed, learned new skills, and tackled challenging projects. It paints a complete picture of who you are as a professional.


Networking and Collaboration
In the geospatial world, connections are everything. Sharing your portfolio with peers and industry leaders can open doors to new opportunities. It’s a great conversation starter and a way to network effectively. Moreover, collaborating with others becomes easier when they can quickly understand your expertise and previous work.


Making a Strong Online Presence
In today’s digital age, having an online portfolio is a must. It enhances your online presence and makes you more discoverable. Potential employers, clients, or collaborators often start their search online. By having a portfolio, you increase your chances of being found and considered for exciting opportunities. Think of it as your digital business card!


Inspiring Others
Your portfolio can be a source of inspiration for other geospatial professionals and researchers. By sharing your work and experiences, you contribute to the community, offering insights and sparking new ideas. It’s a wonderful way to give back and foster a collaborative spirit in the industry.


How to Get Started
Now that you’re convinced of the benefits, let’s talk about how to get started. Here are some tips for creating an outstanding geospatial portfolio:

Choose the Right Platform: Select a platform that suits your needs. Websites like GitHub, Behance, or even a personal website can be great options.
Organize Your Work: Categorize your projects by type, such as GIS analysis, remote sensing, or cartography. Make it easy for viewers to navigate.
Include Descriptions: For each project, include a brief description of the objectives, methodologies, tools used, and the results. Highlight your role and contributions.
Use Visuals: Geospatial work is inherently visual. Include maps, charts, and other visuals to make your portfolio engaging.
Keep It Updated: Regularly update your portfolio with new projects and achievements. An outdated portfolio can do more harm than good.
Get Feedback: Don’t hesitate to ask colleagues or mentors for feedback. They can provide valuable insights to improve your portfolio.



Conclusion
Creating a professional portfolio might seem like a daunting task, but it’s worth the effort. It’s a powerful tool that can significantly impact your career in the geospatial field. So, what are you waiting for? Start building your portfolio today and watch your professional opportunities soar!
Happy mapping, and may your geospatial journey be filled with exciting discoveries and achievements!

title: About Us
text: geo:truth: Non-profit research focused on uncovering health disparities and global challenges using geography.

title: About Us
text:
Our Mission
We believe that the truth is worth discovering.
geo:truth is dedicated to leveraging geospatial insights, epidemiology, and data analytics to address health inequalities and foster healthier communities worldwide. By integrating cutting-edge technology with a commitment to equity, we strive to create a future where access to quality healthcare is not determined by zip code, income, or background.

title: About Us
text:
Our Approach
We employ a multidisciplinary approach, combining expertise in geospatial analysis, epidemiology, and programming to identify and understand the complex factors influencing health outcomes. Through collaborative research, community engagement, and advocacy, we work to implement data-driven solutions that empower underserved populations and promote systemic change.

title: About Us
text:
What We Do

Geospatial Analysis: We utilize state-of-the-art mapping and spatial analysis techniques to visualize health disparities, identify high-risk areas, and inform targeted interventions.
Epidemiological Research: Our team conducts rigorous epidemiological studies to uncover the root causes of health inequities and develop evidence-based strategies for prevention and intervention.
Capacity Building: We provide training and technical assistance to empower local organizations and healthcare providers with the tools and knowledge to address health disparities in their communities.
Advocacy and Policy: We advocate for policies and initiatives that promote health equity and ensure that vulnerable populations have access to the resources and support they need to thrive.

title: About Us
text:
Get Involved
Join us in our mission to build a healthier, more equitable world. Whether you’re a researcher, practitioner, advocate, or concerned science citizen, there are many ways to get involved with geo:truth. Together, we can make a difference and create lasting change for generations to come.

title: Projects
section: Spatial Analysis: Interplay between Armed Conflict, Livelihood, Environmental Factors and Malaria Risk in Sudan
text:
Spatial Analysis: Interplay between Armed Conflict, Livelihood, Environmental Factors and Malaria Risk in Sudan





Analysis Findings
Distance to Another Malaria Case:  This was significant factor in disease risk, which makes sense. Being close to another malaria case, as a factor for malaria acquisition.
Distance to an Armed Conflict Event:  This was also a significant factor in malaria risk. It has been know that are strong linkages between the environment and conflict and has indirect impacts such as population displacement, lack of centralized governance, famine, conflicted-related resource exploitation, under-investment in sustainable development and poor access to health and health services increasing a disease risk for affected populations [2][3]. Competition over oil and gas reserves, Nile water between neighboring countries and tribes and land use issues pose a strong causative link to conflict perpetuation and instigation [2]. These issues are interlinked with social, political and economic issues affecting Sudan and its neighboring countries and middle east and western political interests and greed [2]. The cost is the health and lives of affected populations.
Livelihood: Livelihood zones for “Central Rainfed Millet and Sesame” and “Northern Riverine Small-scale Cultivation” and “Western Wadi Cultivation” were significant predictors of disease risk.  
The Northern Riverine Small-scale Cultivation is intertwined with city life, (mentioned later in Urbanicity/Rurality Section). The White and Blue Niles both flowing at different speeds, bring in various minerals that make the soil near it fertile for cultivation. Small-scale cultivation that is intertwined with city life, involves taking advantage of the fertile soil near the White, Blue and Nile Rivers for cultivation of fruits vegetables and sometimes sorghum that is seasonal with the river flow and volume. People are near these small-scale cultivation, live near the river basins also and are dependent on this type of cultivation as a source of their livelihood—which makes sense that they are at risk for malaria. Mosquito vector is dependent on the human host and subtle water to breed, the small-scale cultivation areas near the river are the perfect stage.
There are water channels from the Blue Nile River that irrigate through (a process called: streamline irrigation—channeling water from high to low regions) to the famous Al Gaziera Agricultural Scheme built by Reginald Wingate in 1904: which was an amassed production of cotton and improved the livelihood and economy of Sudan. The Gaziera Agricultural Scheme was one the largest irrigation projects in the world located southeast of the confluence of the Blue and White rivers in Khartoum. If not properly managed, these water channels can be breeding ground for mosquitoes and can pose high health risks for malaria for populations dependent on the channeling of water for agriculture and livelihood.
Central Rainfed Millet and Sesame: while the Northern Riverine Small-scale Cultivation zone is depended on White, Blue and Nile river cultivation, the Central Rainfed Millet and Sesame livelihood zones depend on rain for cultivation of sesame and millet (called “dokhn”). And livelihood in the region of Kordofan, are dependent on rain for growing crops and for livestock.
Western Wadi Cultivation: This region also includes pools of water that are stagnant from the rain and natural water springs. The water springs and water pools, that collect from rain coming from valleys is the source of livelihood for feeding livestock and cultivation of crops. This type of cultivation feeds the western region of the Sudan and includes cultivation for vegetables, and fruits. This region do not include rivers as source of water, so rain is an important feature for livelihood.
Human Cause of Soil Degradation – Overgrazing and Agriculture: Central to Sudan’s economy, livelihood is agriculture. Sudan is known as the “food basket food for the Arab world”, due to its geography and eco-climatic settings. Approximately 1/3 of Sudan is suitable for agriculture and livestock raising and between 65-75% of working populations depend on these two sources for livelihood [1] . These two sources also provide for 43% of the Sudan’s Gross Domestic Product. The sources of livelihood include: “zoora” or sorghum, millet, gum Arabic, cotton, sesame and ground nut, for livestock and animal: sheep, camels, cattle and coastal fish [6].
Overgrazing and agriculture were factors of human interference that has trigged degradation process, and this was significant in our final model in explaining our outcome of malaria risk.
Urbanicity/Rurality: This was particularly surprising that urban areas were more likely to be predictor of malaria risk and this was significant.
In the recent decades as people have moved from rural to urban to find other sources of livelihood, urbanicity might explain our outcome (malaria risk) because in urban areas people tend to live more compactly (extended families of 2 or more generations). In the literature, there was evidence of the anopheles mosquito changing its breeding sites in urban settings due to the poor drainage infrastructure and being able to sustain host blood meals even in urban high structure buildings and in crevices of water-based air conditioners [4][5].
Also, in urban areas, particularly in Khartoum state and neighboring states that share the White and Blue Nile rivers, where we observed higher spatial intensity of malaria cases: there is a “blend” of cultivated land  agricultural practices that are a part of the urban city. For example, in the areas where agricultural fields are a part of the urban landscape—In the livelihood zone: Northern Riverine Small-scale Cultivation–there several types of trees, and crops are grown, and some livestock roaming in parts of the city and these are a part of the livelihood of people in these regions.
In urban areas, people tend to sleep with windows open or sometimes in open rooftops, or with air conditioners, and be active into parts of the night as a part of the city-life and events and occasions that tend to be planned at nighttime due to the heat and high temperatures during the day.
Soil Degradation Type:  Areas that are “stable with permanent agriculture” and “compaction” were good predictors of estimating our outcome: malaria. 1/3 of Sudan’s land is suitable for agriculture and most of the livelihood of people depends on this. Compaction of soil is when heavy machinery is used to compact the soil and this can cause decreases the porosity of the soil [6]. Compaction coupled with erosion is detrimental to the environment and with decreased porosity of the soil, water puddles are formed as a result making a perfect storm for mosquito breeding.
[1] (Elgali, Mustafa, & Bauer, 2010)
[2] (UNEP, 2008)
[3] (Mboera, Mfinanga, Karimuribo, Rumisha, & Sindato, 2014)
[4] (Noor, et al., 2014)
[5] (WHO-EMRO, 2017)
[6] (FEWS NET, 2015)
 
Data + Support - Thank you:
Global Assessment of Human-induced Soil Degradation (GLASOD) | FEWS NET | Malaria Index Survey Sudan | Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project (ACLED) | Ministry of Health Sudan | Mustashfa Al Manateq AlHarra (Hospital of Tropical Diseases)

A non-profit research project focused on uncovering health disparities and global challenges using geography.

We believe that the truth is worth discovering.
            
            





1.   Geospatial Analysis: mapping and spatial analysis techniques to identify health disparities and high-risk areas, and inform targeted interventions.

2.   Epidemiological Research: rigorous epidemiological studies to uncover the root causes of health inequities and develop evidence-based strategies for prevention and intervention.

3.   Capacity Building: training and technical assistance to empower no, give power back to local organizations and healthcare providers with the tools and knowledge to address health disparities in their communities.

4.   Advocacy and Policy: advocate for policies and initiatives that promote health equity and ensure that vulnerable populations have access to the resources and support they need to thrive.

title: Support Our Work
text: At geo:truth, we are driven by the belief that “the truth is worth discovering.” Our non-profit organization is dedicated to uncovering health disparities and global challenges through the power of geography. By combining geospatial insights, epidemiology, and data analytics, we strive to foster healthier, more equitable communities worldwide.

title: Support Our Work
text:
Why Your Support Matters
Your support is crucial in helping us achieve our mission. With your contributions, we can continue to leverage cutting-edge technology and multidisciplinary research to address health inequalities and promote systemic change. Here’s how your support makes a difference:

Advance Our Research: Your donations fund our innovative research projects that utilize geospatial analysis and epidemiological studies to uncover the root causes of health disparities. This research is the foundation for developing targeted interventions and evidence-based strategies to improve health outcomes.



Empower (No, give back power to) Communities: With your help, we can provide training and technical assistance to local organizations and healthcare providers. By building capacity at the community level, we give back power to groups to effectively address health disparities and implement sustainable solutions.



Influence Policy: Your support enables us to advocate for policies and initiatives that promote health equity. Through our advocacy efforts, we work to ensure that vulnerable populations have access to the resources and support they need to thrive.

title: Support Our Work
text:
Ways to Support Us

Buy Us a Cup of Coffee If You’d Like to: Your financial contributions directly impact our ability to conduct research, provide training, and advocate for change. Every donation, no matter the size, helps us move closer to a world where health equity is a reality.


  
  
    
       
  


Volunteer: Share your time and expertise with geo:truth. Whether you are a researcher, practitioner, advocate, or simply passionate about health equity, your skills can help us advance our mission.
Collaborate with Us: Collaborate with geo:truth on research projects, community initiatives, or advocacy campaigns. Together, we can amplify our impact and drive meaningful change.
Spread the Word: Help us raise awareness about the importance of health equity and the work we do at geo:truth. Follow us on social media, share our research, and encourage others to join our cause.

title: Support Our Work
section: Join Us in Making a Difference
text:
Join Us in Making a Difference
At geo:truth, we believe that by working together, we can create a healthier, more equitable world. Your support is essential in helping us uncover the truth and make a lasting impact on global health. Join us in our mission to build a future where health is a fundamental right for all.
Thank you for your support.
